text: having first been duly sworn by Kathleen S. Norton Connecticut License #105, was examined and testified as follows: DIRECT EXAMINATION
All right.  Good morning, Mr. Jones.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Good morning.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: My name is Suzanne Frare and I represent Charles Shaffer in this lawsuit brought by you regarding an accident that happened March 13, 2018 and I'm going to ask you some questions related to that.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you ever testified before in a deposition?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So there's just a few ground rules. As you can see, there is a reporter in the room that is going to take down what is said, so as much as possible we need to avoid speaking at the same time. Even if you know what my question is going to be, let me finish my question before you begin your answer and I will try to do the same thing. Please answer verbally as you have been. If you just nod your head or shrug your shoulders the reporter can't take down your response.  Okay?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: All right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: If I ask you something that you don't understand, just let me know. Also, if for some reason you need to take a break, just let me know that.  As long as there is no pending question that shouldn't be a problem.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What's your date of birth?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: And can you tell me your Social Security number and, for the record, we'll just put the last four digits, but if you can tell me the whole thing.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: (Portion off the record) 1280.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And where were you born?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I was born in Hartford, Connecticut.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And are you married?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Separated.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What's your wife's name?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Cynthia.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And her maiden name?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Hodge.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have any children?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How many?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Three.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And can you tell me their names and ages?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Ethan is the oldest, he's 24.  And then Elizabeth just turned 20 last week and Schaller is turning 17 tomorrow.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Happy birthday.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Thank you.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what's your address?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: My address where I'm staying now is 627 Old Colchester Road, Amston, Connecticut.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Spell that.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: A-M-S-T-O-N.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And is it a private house or an apartment?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: It's a house that I rent.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how long have you been renting?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: We have been separated for over two years. This place here I just moved into four months ago.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And where were you before that?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I'm at -- my mailing address or where she is at is going to be 22 Stage Coach Run in Cobalt, Connecticut.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that's your mailing address?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when did you live there?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I last lived there -- well, we bought the place in 2006.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you moved out about two years ago?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What's your highest level of education?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I finished high school and I do have some time with the Air Force Academy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And where did you finish high school?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: East Hampton, Connecticut.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when were you in the Air Force?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Twice.  I was in from 1989 to 1992 and I reenlisted when I became salary at Pratt & Whitney in 2001.  And I got activated at 9/11, so I did another two and a half years active duty.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you deployed?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Overseas to Germany, not to ....
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I still thank you for your service.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Thank you.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What's the highest rank?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Technical sergeant.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And generally what did you do in the Air Force?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I was a crew chief, an aircraft mechanic.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you basically have that role --
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes, the entire time.  Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- the entire time?  Okay. And can you tell me generally what a crew chief does?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: He maintains the entire airplane, basically all hydraulic systems, engines, airframe.  That's how I started my career.  I have my A&P license for aviation.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And who do you work for now?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Right now my primary job is Pratt & Whitney United Technologies.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what do you do there?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Right now I'm the AWW operations manager for assembly and test, which is Alternate Work Week, Friday, Saturday, SUnday.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm sorry.  Say that again?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: It stands for Alternate Work Week which is the Friday, Saturday, Sunday shift.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Is that a full-time position?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So how many hours?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: You work 12 hours, 6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. or 6:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m.  I work the 6A to 6P, the first shift.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You work 36 hours and get paid for 40.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how long have you been doing that?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: That position itself or how long have I been at Pratt?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: This is the current position that you have?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: That's the current position.  I have been doing that about two years.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what were you doing prior to that?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: My entire Pratt & Whitney career or -- I can tell you what I started off as.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Tell me the general history, yeah.  I don't want to spend too much time.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I started off as engine mechanic and then from there I traveled for Pratt and got offered a job to run the engine test facility in Middletown back in 2000.  So then I became a supervisor there and then worked my way up through the ranks, supervisor, cell leader.  And then I troubleshot jet engines for Pratt for six years from their global operations center.  It kind of looks like NASA.  Everybody calls in and tells us their problems and we try to help them out over the phone.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: And then, from there, they offered me the position to run the Alternate Work Week, or Test and Assembly, based on my previous experience of running tests.  So I have been in this position for going on two years.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: For about two years?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At the time of this accident you were working in that position?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I was working there, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you tell me when you started with Pratt & Whitney?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I started with Pratt & Whitney in 1998.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now you said you also have another job?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: For Northeast Auto and Truck.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Northeast Auto and Truck.  Is that the name of the company?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What do you do for them?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I'm their tow truck driver.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how long have you been employed there?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I have been employed there I believe since 2009.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how often do you work?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I work -- I used to work nights and weekends when I didn't work the Alternate Work Week shift.  I was their on-call recovery wreck driver. Whenever accidents happen they call me in.  I work off a commission.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So are you salaried or hourly or something else for them?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Well, again, it's commission.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Commission?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Whatever the end of the final bill is I make a percentage of that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How often would you say you work for them?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: How often?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Well, for right now, because I'm on the Alternate Work Week shift, I actually work for them Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday.  I'm on call 24/7.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So for those three days you're on call 24/7?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What would you say in an average week over the last two years?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I probably go out about anything from four to 14 times.  It's a cyclical business.  It gets very busy.  You're either wide open or it's slow.  But we tow for insurance companies and do other things.  At a minimum I go out four or five times a week.  But if it's on a night or a day like that was, that was the first wreck of the day, but normally that would have been a very long day for me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that because there was a snowstorm?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  That's what I'm saying.  Like I said, it depends.  It's probably the only business you like it when it rains or you like it when it snows.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: A lot of work, right?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So probably the most you go out is about 14 times?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  And it depends.  It's such a -- it all depends how people want to drive.  Some days for no reason at all you're very busy and days where it's snowing out and you'd think you'd be very busy you get one or two calls.  It all depends how everyone is driving.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you say on average how many hours a week you work?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Again, it depends on where the tow is to. It depends on it could be a local tow.  Could be -- there are times when I have to go all the way to Pennsylvania, Maine, if people are breaking down that live in that state sometimes the insurance companies pay me to tow them all the way home.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that often that you have to do a long distance tow?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.  It's a couple of times a year.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And so is it fair to say at Pratt & Whitney you're working about 36 hours a week?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then as the tow truck, what do you work?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I would say probably -- if it's -- we average it out to where I'm doing six to eight calls a week.  I try to do probably 10 to 12 hours.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: 10 to 12 hours a week?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's kind of an average week?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you miss any time from work on either of these jobs?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Well, again, when it happened I had the luxury of not having to go to Pratt for a couple of days, so I took a couple of days off from the accident because they put me on muscle relaxers and I didn't feel right driving the truck.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Other than a couple of days taking off?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, I can't afford to take time off. I have a lot of things going on.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you buckled up and you were able to get into work?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you make a workers' comp claim?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.  Again, it's a very small company, mom-and-pop operation.  I didn't want to put that burden on them.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So there was no claim made?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: The only claim that was made I believe was the original emergency room visit.  After that everything else was through my regular insurance.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  All right.  Just to finish up here, at Pratt & Whitney is that a physical job that you have?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I haven't had to physically work since 2000 when I went salary because it's a union shop.  I can't physically do anything other than direct people on what to do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: My husband works for Pratt & Whitney.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So can you tell me generally what you do in this position?  Is it a desk job?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes, a desk job.  A lot of running the entire facility.  There's a lot of, you know, a lot of walking.  There's a lot of overhead work which is why, you know, I've got to have this thing eventually fixed.  Most jet engines, they're not at level, they're just too big or they're up in the test facility so I'm constantly looking up.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you reaching or --
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, no.  But everything that we're doing is overhead work.  And that's why this pain bothers me. By the end of the day all the stuff I'm doing, it's just a burning sensation that just won't go away.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And as a tow truck operator, can you tell me about the physical aspect of that?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: It's basically like on -- a thing like this it's mechanical work and it's a lot of -- especially accidents.  Accidents is what I like doing because you have to figure out how to get the car back up the bank or back off its roof.  Sometimes it's challenging, but for the most part it's not accidents.  A lot of it is just breakdowns and stuff, so it's easy work.  But it's -- it does have its physical times when, again, the car is down the bank.  You have to manipulate everything, figure out how to get it up and all this other stuff.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And get it on the wrecker?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yeah.  And as far as strenuous, you try to make the wrecker do the work for you.  A lot of winching, cables, pulleys.  You don't kill yourself when you have the equipment to do it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you always drive the same vehicle?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, no.  There's three different vehicles. There's this one, which was my main vehicle because it's the newest vehicle and he doesn't really trust a lot of other people driving it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And this vehicle, just so we're clear, what kind of vehicle is it?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: That's a 2006 Nissan UD.  It's a cab forward.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And it's like a flatbed truck?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how often would you say that you drive that particular one?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: That's the main one.  I drive that all the time unless someone else is on call and they call me for backup I will drive the other wreckers.  Sometimes it's a multiple vehicle accident.  Sometimes it's an accident way down the bank where you need to use the boom truck.  Since I know what I'm doing, they'll call me out with the boom truck to recover it back up to the street to get it on the flatbed for the guy that's working that day.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said there were two other vehicles?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yeah, there's two other wreckers.  One of them is a four-wheel-drive forward and the other one is a 99 International Flatbed like this one, but it's not a -- the UD is the primary one we use because it's got an excellent turning radius if you get into dealership parking lots it's much easier to maneuver around.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Even though it's such a big vehicle?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Even though it's such a big vehicle because it's a cab forward that's the one you want to be in.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So let's, at this point, turn to the accident.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: March 13, 2018, is that the date?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember what day of the week it was?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, no.  I don't remember what day of the week.  I can tell you it had to be most likely a Monday, Tuesday or Wednesday.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Because those are the days you work?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And about what time did the accident take place?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: This was the first one of the day so it would have been early in the morning, probably right during rush hour, I would say, between 8:00 and 9:00 or 10:00.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In the morning?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And where did the accident happen?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: This would have been Route 2 eastbound Exit 13.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And in what town?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Marlborough.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the weather conditions you told me, it was snowing?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was it a big snowstorm?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: It was your average.  For me that's an average snowstorm.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was it snowing at the time of the accident?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Ice and snow on the roadway?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Uh-hum.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was the roadway closed at all?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: It was closed when this happened.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Because of this?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Because of this.  Between the wrecker and the car went across all the lanes, so they closed the road.  It was -- there was an officer in front of the UD which you can't see.  There's like a Suburban type of vehicle there, all-wheel-drive.  And then behind the wrecker scene -- I don't know if any of these pictures show it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Just for the record, we previously marked four photos that were provided by you; is that right?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Right.  So this was the -- prior to this happening -- I'm sorry -- this vehicle was in front of me.  When the accident happened, he went around to block traffic there.  But prior to the turn, you can see the lights where they stopped the traffic.  There were two other officers behind me about a hundred yards apart to slow traffic down and make sure people are moving to the right-hand lane.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So just so I'm clear, when this accident occurred you were already at the accident scene?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  So without the car being there, this is where the truck was positioned, maybe a little further back because it got pushed forward, and this trooper was in front of me helping the people with the car.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So let's start with, what were you responding to before this accident happened?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: This would have been the scene right there. I was on the side.  After I evaluated --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: This is Exhibit 1.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  After I evaluated where the car was versus the -- there's like rope rails right here -- determined that I had to pull it up through the side. So that's when I was reaching -- I was inside the cab reaching behind the front seats.  We have to keep what is called loop straps in the cab because if they get wet they freeze up and you can't use them at all.  So I was reaching behind the cab to get the loop straps to put to the side of the tires and do a side pull to pull the car up.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So there was a car off the road?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  That's it right there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What kind of car?  It's hard to see.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I would have to look that up.  I do this so often.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It was a car as opposed to an SUV?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes, it was a car.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the van was to the left side of the road?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes, this is the left-hand lane.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I see, is this area where the yellow line is, is that the shoulder of the road?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you had responded to remove that?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: And I couldn't pull right up on the car because, again, the trooper was there making sure that the people in the car were okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And how long had you been at the accident scene before the accident happened?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Probably five minutes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And in those five minutes you had actually gotten out of your vehicle?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Uh-hum.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when the accident occurred with my client's vehicle, you said you were reaching in?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  I was reaching in the cab over the seats because behind the seats is where we keep all the equipment that can't get wet.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you're reaching in on the passenger side?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  I'm reaching over into the passenger side behind the seats here.  There's three things of what we call straps.  There's all different kinds depending what you're going to do and that's where the loop straps were.  I was reaching over this seat here behind the other one.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were your feet on the ground?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: My feet would have been on the first step. So the door was open and my feet were on the step and I'm receiving over to grab the loop straps.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And just as detailed as you can, were both feet -- you know, the position of your body, like both feet on the step?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  More than likely both feet were on the step there as I'm reaching behind the front seat.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Did you anticipate the accident before it happened?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why don't you describe to me what happened.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Okay.  So I'm reaching behind the front seat to grab the loop straps.  All of a sudden, I got lunged into -- again, because it's a cab forward so the windshield is straight and then there's the dash. I got lunged forward into the windshield and then I ended up down between the seats and the dash.  And as soon as that happened I thought the worst. I thought somehow the truck rolled forward because the brake system is there and I'm like, "Oh my God."  I was freaking out.  "What just happened?"  Because, again, the last thing I saw was the officer and the two people in front of me so I thought the truck rolled forward.  I thought the worse, "Oh my God."
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You thought your truck had moved?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  When that happened, again, my adrenaline is flowing.  I'm "Holy cow."  I jumped out, ran to the front of the truck, and I'm going "What?" And then I realized the officer is still in front of me far enough away.  I'm, "What's going on?"  And the officer screams, "I think someone ran into the back of your vehicle," and I came around and saw it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you didn't even realize what had happened?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I didn't even realize what had happened because, again, I was so concentrated on -- I thought I ran into the people in the truck in front of me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you jumped in front of the truck?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  I jumped out and ran in front of the truck.  And again, when I saw the officer there everybody is looking at me, "What just happened?"  And I'm looking at them, "What the heck just happened?" Because now, again, once I saw there were -- everything was where it was supposed to be I'm like, "Okay, what is going on?"  And the cop is, "I think someone ran into behind you."
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the cop was there and the people from the original accident?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were they all standing outside?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: They were all -- I believe to the -- when I saw them they were all on the side of the car still, out of the vehicle though, when it was snowing.  And again, it's a good thing he was still there getting information on what happened in the accident because otherwise I'm usually telling them to get into the cab of the truck for their safety because they don't want to be off the side of the road.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So nobody else was in the truck?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Nobody else.  It was me leaning across the front seat getting the loop straps.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did they see the car running into the truck?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, because they were off to the side here, but the officer must have put two and two together and said, "Somebody must have slammed into the back of your truck," and then we both walked around.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And your truck, when this happened, your truck was in the position as is shown in Exhibit 1 here?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  I think it got pushed forward.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So we're looking at Exhibit 3, just for the record?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I see.  So the tire marks are in the snow?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: That's where his car hit, but it got pushed forward, too, because it was snowing at the time, so that was from him when we removed the car from underneath it because eventually, like I said, they closed the whole highway down and that's the first time I ever spoke to the individual.  I said, "Hey, does your car still start?"  And he said yes and I said, "All right.  Let's see if it will back out from underneath to get traffic flowing again," and he did that and parked behind the wrecker.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: These photographs, did you take them?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  The officer asked me to take them.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And Exhibit 1 here and Exhibit 2, was this -- the vehicles weren't moved after the accident?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, no.  That's prior to moving them, but once he moved out I took pictures of the controls and how he hit the rear of this to push the mudflap right up on top of the ....
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And so Exhibit 3 and Exhibit 4 is after the car was moved?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: And I took this one just to show my boss because I wasn't sure I would be able to do anything at that point because the controls, I wasn't sure if they would work.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did this control?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: This controls the bed of the truck and the winch.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And just for the record, Exhibit 4, we're looking at the controls here?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And so the two that are bent --
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: They're not supposed to be bent.  This whole thing got pushed up and we had to redo the whole control mechanism surface there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was it able to work after the accident?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I worked it from the other side.  These were -- we disconnected these and -- there's controls on both sides.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: They're the same controls?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  They look exactly the same but they're not messed up.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I see.  And Exhibit 3 is just a further away picture?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you said from Exhibit 3 you believe that the truck -- your vehicle actually moved from the impact?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes, because he hit the controls and then hit the rear end.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The tire?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: So, and that's, when he did that, that's what threw me forward because we didn't know it at the time but later, like four months later, we had to replace all the brake parts on that side because when the emergency brake was on, this has air brakes, so when the emergency brake was set this side controls, and like I said we didn't know it at the time but they all broke off.  When I was using my emergency brake, it was only that side that was catching but we wouldn't have known that unless -- we finally figured it out because we were on a hill one time and all of a sudden it was rolling forward and that's when we figured out it had to be from when he hit the....
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Just to be clear, at the time you were stopped, before the accident, you had the emergency brake on?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then from the impact of the accident, there was a problem with the emergency brake?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: And again, we didn't know it at the time. None of that went through the insurance company or anything, we just fixed it.  We were like that's from the accident because the other side was fine.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And obviously the control panel that you were telling me about had to be replaced and that was damaged in the accident?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there any other part of the truck damaged in the accident?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.  Again, he's kind of lucky.  The car went underneath the bed.  So when he pulled out it settled back down, but it's up a little bit here because his hood is underneath it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there damage to the underneath part of the truck?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, because, again, the only thing in the way are the controls.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's good because the truck stopped the car from going underneath?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  Again, there's so much more scenarios that could have been worse.  I could have been at the controls.  The bed could have been down.  He would have went over the top of me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the people in the car, you can go on and on?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Do you know the names of the people?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What about the officer, is he the one that filled out the police report?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I don't know the officers' names.  There were three or four of them.  Like I said, there was him and then there were two more officers behind us but I don't know if there were multiple officers in the car, so I don't know who made the report out.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And as far as you know no one saw the car slide in, it was after?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Because, again, traffic was flowing, but we were flowing in one lane on the other side.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the officers had blocked which lane?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: They blocked the left lane behind me probably a good four hundred yards behind us.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: And again, there was one there and one even further back with his lights on to get people to slow down first.  And then the other one was moving people over to get by this scene because, again, the right lane was open.  There was no reason to close the highway down.  And they typically don't.  They never, unless it's blocking more than one lane they won't close the highway.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So I know you were telling me what happened to your body when this happened.  You hit the windshield, you said?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What part of your body hit the windshield?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: The back of my head.  I was reaching over the seat and it threw me this way and the windshield is right there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did it crack the windshield?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And can you tell me, again, what other parts of your body hit what inside the vehicle?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Again, I got tossed around so it was --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I know it's a very difficult question.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I can tell you I ended up on the floor in between the seats and the dash and that is a very tight area.  So I was this way, so I had to, you know -- and again, I was so jacked up from adrenaline thinking I might have ran over somebody in front of me, but....
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In the front seat is it like a bench seat or two?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: There's two.  The seat that I drive in, the driver's seat, is an air ride seat because it's a big truck so when I ride in the seat when you're going over bumps it cushions the impact.  And then there's the middle has an arm rest which flips up to another seat and then there's a passenger seat which is the same as mine but it's not an air ride seat.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And so you were reaching over the passenger seat at the time?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  I was reaching up.  That middle section is a raincoat coat that's on a hangar.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is there a back seat to the cab?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.  It's just -- behind the cab, it's an extra cab, but that is for tool storage.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that's where you were reaching?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: That's what I was reaching behind to get the straps.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And your head hit the actual windshield, right?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you ended up your whole body on the floor?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: My whole body between the seats and the dashboard.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was your head where the driver's seat was?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: It was in the middle, I assume, only because I was reaching over.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have any visible injury?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: My shoulder was a little bit black and blue.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's your left shoulder?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And where was the bruising to your shoulder?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: It was up here.  (Indicating)
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The top?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes, the top.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any photos of that?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.  It wasn't -- again, it didn't really go black and blue for a day or so.  That wasn't their main concern at the emergency room.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I understand.  I was just asking the details. Okay.  So your head hit the windshield and your body ended up on the floor?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any other part of your body hitting anything else that you can recall?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Not that I can recall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Afterward you were able to get out immediately?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Oh, yes.  I ran to the front.  I didn't even look in the back.  If I looked in the back I would have noticed what happened, but I ran toward the front of the vehicle because I wanted to make sure everybody was all right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Because, again, I thought it was something I did.  I didn't assume somebody slammed into the back of the truck.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you hear the impact or anything?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.  Well, all the impact I heard was like inside the cab.  Yes, I heard it but I thought it was me hitting someone in front of me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Oh, okay.  And did you feel the impact?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Again, my adrenaline -- so, again, if it was just a normal thing where I didn't think I might have done, you know, something in front of me, I probably would have said yes, I felt it then.  But I was so fired up on what the heck, trying to figure out what happened.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So right after you went over to the officer?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And to the occupants of the other vehicle?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you describe the occupants of the other vehicle?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yeah.  It was a middle-age couple.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you go over to the red car?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: This one?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: After.  When the officer said that, "Hey, I think someone slammed in behind you," and so I'm back there and so the officer went over and he started to talk to the guy, but I was looking at the car and what happened and I was like, "Oh, God."
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, I know your adrenaline and everything, but immediately after the accident were you feeling any pain or aware of any injuries?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Again, they asked me, the officers asked me if I wanted, you know, I said, I know, "I'm banged up, but no one else is on duty."  My boss was in the other truck at the other end of the highway.  I said, "I'm good," because they said, "We'll call an ambulance." They kept asking me, "I will call an ambulance." I said, "I'm good.  If I leave the truck there nothing will get done.  The highway will stay closed.  I will go afterwards.  Don't worry.  I will figure out what's going on."
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So there was no one to replace you with the tow truck?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, because if my boss is in the other truck there is no one to come grab this one.  Even when he showed up, we would have had to leave one truck there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But can you tell me what you were feeling at the time right after this happened, the best you can?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yeah, just, you know, breathing hard.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But --
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I mean, at that time, I'm a tough guy. Even if I was hurting I would have sucked it up.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm just trying to get an idea of what you were feeling right when this happened.  I mean, right after this happened.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Right after it happened?  I'm just like that explains everything that happened in the cab, you know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I mean, were you feeling pain to any particular part of your body?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Well, yeah.  Again, I was bruised up but it wasn't anything that I was going to stop, you know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I understand you were able to keep going but with some difficulty?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Right, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But can you tell me, I know you had bruising to your shoulder.  Was there any other bruising to any other part of your body after the accident?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, everything was just burning.  But again, I have had -- I've pulled my leg, that type of burning, so you figure it's going to stop.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And where was the burning, to what part of your body?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: It was on my upper neck.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In the back, right?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Any other part of your body?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you able to continue to tow the original vehicle?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I stayed there until my boss showed up and my boss did the majority of the work.  I just drove the vehicle back.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What's your boss's name?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Danny Cafro; C-A-F-R-O.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what about the red car?  Did you tow that?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: That one got towed with the other truck that he brought out.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That Danny brought out?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you ever speak to the driver of the red car?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yeah.  Like I said, after we realized the highway was closed, because it was two lanes, that's when I went over.  And the first thing I asked him was if he was all right.  He said yeah and I said, "Does your car start?"  He said yes, so I said, "If the car starts we're going to get this one out of the way so they can reopen the highway."  And the officer that was there said it was perfect, so that's what we did. We had him start it up, put it in reverse, and slowly back out.  Then he drove around and put the car behind the truck.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then they were able to open the roadway, right?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So what did you do after the accident?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: After the accident, again, I just -- Danny did all the work.  You know, he got the car up.  He pulled the truck forward, got the car up, and then he loaded it up on the bed and then he loaded this car on his truck and I drove back to the shop.  There's a turn-around up the street a little ways, so maybe I went a mile up the street, did the turn-around to get into the westbound lane for the emergency vehicles and got back.  And once I got back I said, "All right. I'm going to head up to the emergency room to have them look at this."  He said, "That's fine," that he would take care of all the rest and unloaded the vehicles and did all of that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you brought the tow truck back to your office?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes, the business.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And where's that?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: That's at 394 North Main Street in Marlborough.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how far was that from the accident?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: From that point right there I can tell you it's exactly two miles.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And were you involved in unloading either of the vehicles?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.  I just brought the vehicle through the gate, got out, and -- I'm trying to think.  Oh, yeah. Danny handed me -- I said, "I'm going to the emergency room," and he handed me their workmen's comp number, I guess it was, and he said, "Just give them that."
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: For the emergency room?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you drive yourself to the emergency room?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Anyone go with you?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what emergency room did you go to?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: That was the Marlborough.  They changed the name on it so many times but it's the Middlesex Hospital Clinic.  It's a 24-hour.  That's where everybody goes that gets into an accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that right near --
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: It's right off the exit where our shop is at, so it's literally a mile, two miles up the street. Probably a mile because it's two miles from here.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And when you got there were you seen right away?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what were your -- was it still the same complaints, the burning to the neck?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  I told the doctor when I went in, the first thing they did is they took my blood pressure and immediately put me in a neck brace.  When I got into the -- what do you call it, the room there that they put you in, I had the neck brace on and it actually hurt more.  That's when I told the doctor, "You've got this neck brace on me now.  It's absolutely killing me."  He said, "It's procedure.  We have to do it that way."  And that's when they took me from there in the back to have whatever they do at the hospital.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: CT scan?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  I think that's what it is.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any other type of testing did they do?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yeah.  They did whatever they do when you go in there.  At this point I'm like, "Get this off me."  I said, "You're absolutely killing me having this on my neck.  It hurts like crazy."  He said, "We can't until we figure out what's going on."
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So they took the CT scan?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did they take you anywhere else for testing or x-rays?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.  Everything they did was in the room there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what did they do?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Physically he was looking with his hands and stuff.  And again, it just was excruciating pain. Again, I don't understand why they -- I understand they've got procedures, but having that neck brace on really, really made things worse.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long did you have to have it on for?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Probably -- I guess I was there for a couple of hours.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did they give you any medication?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  They gave me some muscle relaxers.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember the names?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I think it's in the medical report.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I have the report.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: It's like a different language.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how long did you take the muscle relaxers?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I took them for two days.  They made my stomach so upset I stopped taking them.  That's why I saw my normal doctor to see if there was anything else because my stomach was a disaster with what they gave me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did they give you any other pain medication?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: They told me to take the high dose ibuprofen.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Over-the-counter?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  They said take up to 800 or a thousand.  I forget what they said.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you do that?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  And I have been doing that, unfortunately, for the past -- since this happened.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, at the time within 24 hours of the accident, had you had any type of medication?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any type of medication that you were supposed to take that you failed to take?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any alcohol?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, I don't.  I'm DOT tested here and at Pratt & Whitney so it's not something....
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Did they give you a neck brace to take home from the hospital?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.  At that point after they did their CT scan they said, "If it's bothering you, you don't have to wear it," so I said okay.  And when I left they said, "Make sure you see your regular doctor," and that's what we ended up doing.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how did you leave the hospital?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: With my prescriptions in hand and back in the car.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you drive yourself?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  At that time I was living literally a half a mile from the -- I was living at 77 South Main.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that's less than a mile from the hospital?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And you followed up with your primary?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that Dr. Spada?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Spada, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I might be saying it wrong.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, I might be saying it wrong.  Everybody says his name differently.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: We know who you're talking about. When did you follow up with him?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I would like to say the following week or two.  Again, because of my schedule it's tough to get in to see the doctor right away so....
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It looks like the 28th which is about two weeks.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And at that time what were your --
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Same symptoms.  That's why I told him, I said, "Listen, I didn't take the muscle relaxers because they were making my stomach so upset."  I was taking the ibuprofen and I said, "The pain is still there.  But the funny thing is it's not there after I wake up, I'm fine.  About in an hour or two I can start feeling it.  At the end of the day it's like someone has a hot poker in my back."  And that's the way it's been since then.  And again, at the time I didn't know why, but eventually we found out why.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Had you ever had any pain like that in your neck?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, never.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Ever any medical treatment to your neck?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At this time when you went to your primary and you had this excruciating pain you described, did it just stay in the back of your neck?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  It's -- like right now it's right here, but it shoots down my shoulder, but the burning is right there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At the base of your neck in the back?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  It's to the right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: To the right?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  And the whole time during physical therapy I would always point to it and say, "It hurts right there."  This is what we're going to do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did it go down your right shoulder or right arm?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: It goes -- the pain, the full day, at the end of the day the pain is really bad at the neck, but you can feel it in the shoulder because of just the way the nerves go.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did it radiate at all into the left side?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Just the back of the neck on the right side?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Just the right side.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And is this something you continue to have every day?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  Some days are better depending on any activity.  If I don't do anything it's a better day. If I go out and do miniscule things, even if it's getting in this thing and driving it, just the constant shifting, it just starts to burn after a while.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And driving the truck, it's a stick shift?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And are you right-handed?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So when you saw your primary, what did he to, if anything?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: He did basically the same thing they did in the emergency room.  He checked my back and checked everything and he looked at -- I think he looked at what he had, the film that he had there, and said, "I can see why they released you because you really can't see on there what they did, if there's any major damage, but my assumption is this."  That's when he said he thought I would benefit from physical therapy anyways.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So did you go to physical therapy?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes, I did.  Ten weeks of physical therapy with Ryan.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Had you ever had physical therapy before?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Never.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did it help at all?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: At first I wanted to strangle him because it seemed like -- it really aggravated it.  And then he explained, "Let's to through it," and we went through it and ended up finding a couple of exercises that helped.  You can definitely tell it was helping, certain things we were doing.  And he said, "Okay, let's keep that up."  But again, at the end of the day I would just still have this burning sensation.  The exercises I could do and it would help for like an hour.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Then it would go back to the same?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  It always returned to that same burning at night.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And this would happen while you were sleeping, too?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Well, trying to sleep.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did it interfere with sleep?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  That's the whole problem with it burning like that, it's hard to find a position.  It's let's try this and then if I get to sleep I will wake up fine.  But the problem is being on call you find a position, you get to sleep, and then two hours later the phone is going off, "Hey, there is a breakdown" or "a wreck," and you get up, come back, and start the whole process all over again.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have to take anything to help you sleep?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I take melatonin.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's not prescribed, right?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: It's not prescribed.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Anything else?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: And I take the ZzzQuil.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any other type of medication?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.  Again, I'm very -- I won't take any type of sleeping medication if it's prescribed because when I worked at the Global Operation Center for Pratt, we worked a rotating shift, and I was the only guy out of 16 that had -- they took Lunesta, whatever it was, and the stories they would tell you about the dreams they had I didn't want any part of that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And also three days a week you're on call, right?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So I'm clear, when you work at the -- when you're on call, it's 24/7?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: 24/7.  They prefer it that way because I know what I'm doing and I don't mind being on call because, like I said, it's cyclical.  So I'm off or I'm at home or I get called out for a couple hours, so I like it like that.  The schedule works for me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So how often were you going to physical therapy for those ten weeks?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Three times a week.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then is there a reason you stopped the physical therapy?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  We got to the ten weeks, I guess that's what insurance covers.  I guess they can put in for an extension and I just said that at this point it doesn't seem like -- I'm at a certain point where we know what's happening and we know -- but at the end of the day it was the same result.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you weren't making much progress there?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So did you back to your primary at some point?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I can't remember if I went back to see Dr. Spada or not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you go to another doctor?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I did because, again, once I found out that this was burning and stuff, and I am not a doctor fan so I really don't know any experts, so I asked my attorney if there is someone I should go see and they had a couple of recommendations.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Your attorney recommended that you see Dr. Jambor?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: We went to see Jambor.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when did you do that?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Again, it's very tough to find a doctor that is not going to work through workmen's comp.  As soon as she heard you're not going through workmen's comp, they don't want anything to do with you.  That's why I had to go and say, "Listen, I can't find anyone that will work," and so there was a recommendation to go see him and he was very nice.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what did he do for you?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: He was the one that examined me and really went into depth on what could be done about it.  He said, "Listen, unfortunately, the CT scan" -- he was absolutely right.  He said, "Unfortunately, the CT scan that they did won't see if there's any damage, so you need to go in for your MRI."  He said, "You have to have that done so we can eliminate that there is nothing wrong." And eventually we did the MRI and that is, low and behold, what opened up the whole thing saying, "Here is why you're having the pain."  And I don't understand it.  I don't understand why they don't do that at the hospital right off the bat because I wasted ten weeks of physical therapy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Had you ever had an MRI before?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The MRI, they told you what it showed?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did they have a plan or recommendation for you after that?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: After, when I saw them, they said, "Okay, the worst word we can tell you is extrusion and that's what you have in one of your... the medical term, that's the worst scenario you can have is an extrusion" and he said, "That's what is most likely causing your pain."
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did they tell what you you should do for that?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: They said an extrusion, unfortunately, is called an operable condition and that's the only way to fix it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do surgery?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: They can mask it.  They asked if I wanted to do cortisone shots and I said if it gets to that point where I can't, then I would seek that out as an option, but I just don't need needles into my neck, you know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you try it at all?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I will try it if I have to.  And again, they all said that that would just mask it.  It is not fixing an extrusion, it will fix the pain but not the problem.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: About surgery, did you discuss surgery with Dr. Jambor?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes, but Jambor, he's not a surgeon so he recommended -- he had two or three recommendations and, unfortunately, I ran into the same problem again. As soon as you say that there is no workmen's comp, you're not going through workmen's comp they say, "Sorry, Mr. Jones, we don't deal with accidents."
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you ultimately go to another doctor, Mastrianni?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now does he perform surgery?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: He informed me after the fact, he said, "I'm going to do a consultant.  I can recommend certain surgeons, but ultimately surgery is your choice."  And again, I don't know doctors.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But did you go to him for an opinion or did you go to him for treatment?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, I went to him to find out what my options would be, you know, and then what this condition is.  And he -- actually, he's very knowledgeable.  He had a lot of surgery history.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But he can't perform it?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And so he recommended other surgeons?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you go to any of those?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.  Again, at this point, because I'm the operations manager at Pratt & Whitney, I was the only. I just hired a deputy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Once she is up and trained, which unfortunately doesn't happen overnight, but once she's up and trained I do plan on getting the surgery because I can't go on like this.  But I also can't -- in my position I can't say I need to be out for 8 to 12 weeks.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: There's no one to replace you?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.  I'm the operations manager.  There is no one to replace me, nor would I want someone to -- force someone to say, "Hey, sorry, I'm going out for surgery and you need to work Friday, Saturday and Sunday for the next eight weeks."  That's not something I would do to somebody.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It's difficult because of the schedule?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You recently hired a deputy, you said?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  It will be probably take six months to a year to get her up to speed.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When did you hire her?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Two months ago.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what's her name?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Rosario Puntio.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And so you are planning to have surgery?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you consulted with any surgeons?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, not yet.  Again, I would like to make sure that -- I don't know if you know what it entails, what has to be done.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did they tell you?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Again, you'd think it's the back so they'd come in from here, but they have to cut next to your esophagus, move everything over and try to fuse the disc back in place.  It just gives me the heebies thinking about it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But it's something that you feel you need to do?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: It's something that I know I need to do because everyone, the doctors and everyone, it's operable, the only way to fix it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did they tell you about the risks involved?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So as of right now you don't have any scheduled appointments?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, no.  I want to make sure that I can leave work comfortable.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And you believe that will be when?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I would believe sometime, again, depends on the schedule and depends on -- there's a lot of changing things that happen at Pratt.  Obviously we're combining with another company now so I would say spring.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Are there any other medical treatment or doctors that you went to?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, not that I can think of.  No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the last doctor that you went to, is that Dr. Mastrianni?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And before -- did your attorney recommend him or somebody else?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Well, again, because I was finding everyone I called didn't want to deal with me I reached out for a recommendation.  And I'm actually glad.  He did thousands of those surgeries.  He actually got me to relax a little bit about it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Beforehand, when was the last time you had medical treatment?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I'm not a doctor person, so I don't usually go.  But the last time would have been my annual checkup with Dr. Spada.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then the last --
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I'm sorry.  There was a couple of emergency room examinations where I got something in my eye.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But related to this accident?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, nothing.  Nothing.  No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So related to the accident, did you see Dr. Jambor just two times.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I believe I saw him twice and then his assistant once and I can't remember his assistant's name, because he was out that day, but they assured me when I got to his office that he was very knowledgeable and he actually was.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: From the records I have, it looks like the last time you went was August 23, 2018 about a year ago; is that right?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I guess.  I don't keep a log when I go.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I have the records, but I'm asking you.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So from when you saw him a year ago, other than seeing Dr. Mastrianni one time, have you had any other medical treatment in the last year?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So your current condition, has it changed at all?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.  It just stays steady.  And again, based on all the doctors that I have seen, including, you know, they've all said that, unfortunately, it becomes a harder operation the longer you keep it with the disc slipped or extruded.  The longer you wait, the harder, the more -- the recovery time is going to be longer.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what did they tell you the recovery time was?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Eight to twelve weeks.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you have to be out of work during that time?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: From both jobs?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  Again, they said everyone's recovery is different, so that's why they say eight to twelve.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I understand.  Now, I know you told me it's difficult to look up, that's part of your job?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Uh-hum.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are there any other activities or things you do on a regular basis?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: This is the first year I haven't really because usually come springtime I'm hard and heavy into jogging and going to the gym but I don't do that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How often would you go jogging before the accident?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Three times a week.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How far would you go generally?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Five to seven miles was my route.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you do that year round?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Not during the winter months.  But I would say springtime through probably November.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you been able to go jogging since?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.  I know if I jog like ten minutes this will be burning.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you tried?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Oh, no.  No.  I just know.  Because, again, I -- it's a quarter mile back and forth from my office through the two buildings that I cover and everything, and just walking that route at work it just starts burning.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that's required of your job?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Oh, yeah.  I have to cover the entire two facilities so....
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It's about a quarter of a mile, you said?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: It's about a quarter of mile from my office through the Building 220 and the Building 410 which I also cover so.....
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How much walking would you say you do on an average day for your job?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: When I had a pedometer on me it was nine miles a day.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And so you're still able to do that, but it's difficult?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.  I actually -- when you say "still able to do it," by the end of the day I'm getting in my car and if I have to go to the other building I drive, I don't walk it.  It stinks because I'm constantly starting and stopping.  I don't have a company car so....
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So the nine miles is what you used to do?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: The nine miles is, on a busy day, that's what I used to do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what would you say it is now on average?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: On average, I'd say it's at least five.  If it's busy and there's a problem in 410 and I'm constantly going back and forth it's nine miles a day.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you go to the gym on a regular basis before the accident?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Probably once or twice a week at work. There's a work gym.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have to be a member or through work?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No, it's through work.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And have you been since the accident?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you give me some examples of anything else that's been affected by your injuries from the accident?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Again, I'm always just crazy careful now. It's not like I jump into things and just do them. I pause and think, okay, what's this going to do to affect my day.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Is there anything that you can't do at all other that when you've told us about?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I'm not going to say you can't do at all because if I want to do it I will do it, but it will cause me great aggravation in the end.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Other than jogging or the gym, anything else?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Not that I can think of other than work. I'm a workaholic, unfortunately.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How many hours, combined, the two jobs, would you say you work a week?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I would say a minimum of 36 at Pratt and another 10 to 15 hours so probably 55 to 60 hours a week.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And it's pretty much every day of the week, right?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Well, every week, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Between the two jobs.  Do you ever have a day off?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I take Thursday nights off.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Give me a second.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: (Discussion held off the record.)
Do you have any outstanding medical bills that you know of?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Other than the ones that I kept for the therapy, I know that was over 4,000-some dollars.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did insurance cover it?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Insurance covered it, but I keep getting letters from the insurance company saying, "This looks like this was from an accident, are you currently seeking anything?"  I have to fill out, you know, checks in the boxes and send it back to them.  But I'm sure, depending, I don't know how it works with the operation and all that, that might be....
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: An expense there?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any out-of-pocket expenses?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Other than my co-pays, because I use my -- I have an HSA account, so whenever I go to these it's the co-pay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know the co-pay?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I don't.  I think it's $35 or $25.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have a deductible?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: I'm sure there's a deductible.  Again, I don't keep track because I have money automatically go into the HSA.  Every time they say I owe something, I swipe it and be done with it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Have you ever been convicted of a crime?
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I think that's all I have.  Your attorney may have some questions. MR. O'BRIEN:  No questions.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Thank you very much.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: Thank you.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I hope you feel better.
speaker: MS. FRARE

text: (Deposition adjourned at 11:53 a.m.) TRANSCRIPT CORRECTIONS REPORTER:  KATHLEEN S. NORTON
BENJAMIN JONES vs.
speaker: DEPO OF

text: _________________________________________________ JURAT I, BENJAMIN JONES, do hereby certify that the foregoing testimony given by me on AUGUST 20, 2019 is true and accurate, including any corrections noted on the corrections page, to the best of my knowledge and belief. At _______________________ in said County of __________________, this ______ day of ___________, 2019, personally appeared BENJAMIN JONES, and he made oath to the truth of the foregoing answers by him subscribed. Before me, _____________________, Notary Public.  My commission expires:
